title: Introducing FlyPOP, Britain's newest low-cost long-haul airline
text:
It was unveiled in 2016 – so why hasn’t it launched yet?

Telegraph Travel reported on Navdip Singh Judge’s plans three years ago, when his airline began crowdfunding for the £5m it said was needed to launch.

Put off, perhaps, by those claims to put both “people” and “planet” before “profit”, things have moved pretty slowly. Indeed, the FlyPOP news feed since 2016 has been largely devoted to celebrating key Indian holidays.

But in June it announced the opening of a new corporate HQ at Stansted, the Essex airport from where it plans to fly to Amritsar and Ahmedabad. A sign that flights could soon start? Perhaps.

In a July interview with the website Simple Flying, Singh Judge said he hoped the inaugural flight would be within six months.

But don’t bet your mortgage on it. The airline is still firmly in the funding stage and is yet to receive approval to operate from the Civil Aviation Authority. It now hopes to raise a total of £6m by the end of 2019. Telegraph Travel has contacted it for further comment.
